awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Functional Polymers with Reversible Bonds: The Role of Associating Group Aggregates
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Associating polymers formed by reversible chemical bonds between polymer molecules have unique macroscopic properties and functionalities not achievable in other materials, including self-healing and time-programmable functions. Moreover, they form recyclable plastic materials critical for sustainability. However, detailed quantitative understanding of how to control macroscopic properties of these novel polymeric materials remains a challenge. The proposed research addresses this challenge by combining a broad range of experimental techniques with development and testing of new theoretical model approaches connecting molecular-scale processes to macroscopic properties. The knowledge developed in this research will be central to the rational design of novel recyclable polymers with unique, self-healing, and stimuli-responsive properties. It will have strong impact on various fields of science and engineering, including materials science, physics, chemistry and biophysics. A significant focus of the project is integration with education through active involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in research. The project also promotes active collaborations with national user facilities and international collaborations. 



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Associating polymers, formed by reversible intermolecular interactions, include a wide spectrum of fundamentally and technologically important materials with better recyclability than traditional polymers. Rational design, synthesis, and fabrication of novel associating polymers require a deep fundamental understanding of how the local reversible interactions and phase separation of the associating groups affect the macroscopic properties of these materials. Despite extensive attention and efforts in the past, detailed quantitative understanding of dynamics in the melts of associating polymers remains limited. This hinders development of novel functional materials with desired properties. The main goal of the planned research is to deepen the fundamental understanding of dynamics in associating polymers on different time and length scales with special focus on the role of associating group aggregates. In this research, the chain and segmental dynamics and the viscoelastic properties of associating polymers will be studied by a combination of rheology, dielectric spectroscopy, differential scanning calorimetry, and light- and neutron scattering spectroscopies. It will be complemented by analysis of structure using small angle X-ray and neutron scattering, and will provide broad-based experimental tests of existing theories. The proposed research will deepen fundamental understanding of microscopic parameters controlling macroscopic properties of associating polymers, especially the role of intrinsic heterogeneities. This will be instrumental for a rational design of materials with unique viscoelastic and self-healing properties, as well as for design of novel functional materials with tunable time programmed and stimuli-responsive properties. From a broader perspective, it might also have strong impact on understanding of many biological materials where reversible bonding and interactions play a critical role.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Associating polymers present a relatively new class of materials that can exhibit properties of small molecules or properties of polymers, depending on conditions used. These materials are based on dynamic reversible bonds and exhibit unique self-healing and time programmable abilities, extreme toughness and adhesion, properties important for broad applications in many current and future technologies. Moreover, they are easily recyclable, that improves sustainability of current technologies.  However, our understanding of the dynamics in associating polymers remains limited.

This project was focused on fundamental understanding of mechanisms and molecular parameters controlling dynamics and viscoelastic properties in associating polymers, especially in systems with phase separating dynamic bonds (stickers). Our studies revealed critical role of interfacial polymer layer formed around clusters of stickers in significant enhancement of materials mechanical properties (Figure 1). By tuning concentration of stickers we could change rubbery modulus by more than 100 times (Right Figure 1). Detailed studies also demonstrated that the clusters of stickers enable control of viscoelastic properties of materials independent of the polymer segmental dynamics. The bond rearrangement time and viscous flow in these systems are controlled by structural relaxation in clusters of stickers with additional energy barrier defined by immiscibility of stickers in the polymer matrix. Based on our results, we developed a general model that describes dynamics and viscoelastic properties of polymers with phase separating stickers, unravel the role of stickers concentration and polymer molecular architecture. The developed during this award knowledge is instrumental in design of novel functional materials with unique properties, including self-healing and easy recyclability. Although our studies were focused mostly on systems with hydrogen bonding stickers, the developed models should be applicable to polymers with other types of dynamic bonds, including vitrimers. Using this knowledge, we designed and synthesized materials with unique viscoelastic and self-heling properties, and with extreme recyclability (Fig. 2). This extreme recyclability are critical for reducing plastic pollution affecting our environment.

Besides these scientific achievements, the NSF funding helped significantly in development of human resources and education. Three graduate and three undergraduate students (two of them are female) were actively involved in this research. Two PhD students have graduated and are working now in industry and academia. Also five postdoctoral associates (including one female and one Hispanic) worked on this project and learned how to lead an independent research, mentor students, etc. Two of them got faculty positions and one went to industry, while two other continue work in our group. We also pay attention to working with school students. For several years during Dr. Sokolov presents a lecture to about 100 high school students attending the Governor?s summer school at the University of Tennessee. This school attracts the best high-school students from the entire state of Tennessee. Students from Dr. Sokolov group also participate in Science Olympiad and Tennessee Science Bowl.

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2023
Modified by: Alexei Sokolov
